entry.title: Combined summary - Mailing List Future
entry.summary:
The programming community is at a crossroads with the upcoming closure of its current mailing list, as highlighted in a recent meeting. This has led to deliberations on suitable platforms that could host future discussions. Google Groups emerged as a possible candidate but raised concerns about accessibility for non-Gmail users. Though it's feasible to join without a Gmail account by sending a subscription request to a specific endpoint, the lack of access to the web interface's search and archive features is a notable downside. However, associating a non-Gmail email with a Google Account could circumvent this issue, allowing full use of the group's web interface without switching to Gmail for regular communication.
Groups.io stands out as another alternative, offering seamless email integration and an easy migration from Mailman, the system currently in use. It appeals to those who prioritize email communication but also appreciate a robust web interface. Despite these options, Discourse garners the most favor for its ability to beautifully render images and LaTeX, coupled with organizational tools like tags and categories. Crucially, it offers an 'email list mode' for traditionalists who prefer engaging through email, thereby not alienating members of the community who are less inclined to interact with the website directly.
The conversation then touched upon the prospect of self-hosting a new Mailman instance. The author, presumably Vincent, volunteered to oversee this setup provided it remains fully moderatedâ€”a responsibility deemed manageable at present. Concerns over the potential filtering of emails by spam algorithms, particularly those used by Microsoft, were noted, yet the sentiment was optimistic that thorough moderation would mitigate such issues.
An offer from AJ to establish a section dedicated to lightning discussions on delvingbitcoin.com, which could potentially support a Discourse instance, was also mentioned. The dialogue around these choices remained informal, and no definitive conclusion was reached. To resolve this, a decision was made to hold a vote after a short discussion at the next scheduled meeting, which will take place one week and a day from the time of this correspondence. Participants eager to weigh in or ensure their views are considered have been encouraged to either attend the meeting or respond to the current message, with Matt committing to relay all received feedback during the meeting.
